overview.description: A deeply structured, hands-on introduction to Python programming designed for absolute beginners. This course teaches Python from the ground up, progressing through fine-grained modules and lessons that drill down to specific skills, such as working with variables, data types, string manipulation, if/elif/else conditions, loops (for/while), lists, dictionaries, functions, and beginner project-building. Each lesson includes concepts, micro-exercises, hands-on labs, and knowledge checks to ensure practical understanding.
overview.target_audience: Complete beginners with no prior programming experience who want a structured, step-by-step path to mastering Python fundamentals.
prerequisites: Basic computer literacy (creating folders, opening applications)
Ability to install software such as Python and JupyterLab

modules.title: Getting Started with Python
modules.description: Introduction to Python programming, installation, and basic syntax.
module_outcomes: Learn basic syntax and data types

lessons.title: Installing Python and JupyterLab
lessons.summary: Learn how to install Python and set up JupyterLab for coding.

hands_on_labs.title: Lab: Setting Up Your Environment
hands_on_labs.goal: Successfully install Python and JupyterLab and run a simple script.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Verify Python Installation
micro_exercises.task: Open a terminal and run 'python --version' to check your installation.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Create Your First Notebook
micro_exercises.task: Launch JupyterLab and create a new notebook titled 'My First Notebook'.

knowledge_check.question: What command do you use to check your Python version?
knowledge_check.answer: 'python --version' or 'python3 --version'.

knowledge_check.question: Why is JupyterLab useful for Python programming?
knowledge_check.answer: It provides an interactive environment for writing and testing code.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise
main_exercise.task: Complete the main exercise for Installing Python and JupyterLab

lessons.title: Understanding Python Syntax and Data Types
lessons.summary: Explore the basic syntax of Python and learn about different data types.

hands_on_labs.title: Lab: Exploring Data Types
hands_on_labs.goal: Create variables of different data types and print them.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Create Variables
micro_exercises.task: Define variables for your name, age, and height, and print them.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Identify Data Types
micro_exercises.task: Use the type() function to check the data types of your variables.

knowledge_check.question: What is the purpose of indentation in Python?
knowledge_check.answer: It defines the structure and flow of the code.

knowledge_check.question: Name three basic data types in Python.
knowledge_check.answer: Integers, Floats, and Strings.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise
main_exercise.task: Complete the main exercise for Understanding Python Syntax and Data Types

lessons.title: Variables and Operators
lessons.summary: Learn how to use variables and operators to manipulate data.

hands_on_labs.title: Lab: Calculating with Variables
hands_on_labs.goal: Perform calculations using variables and operators.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Variable Assignment
micro_exercises.task: Create variables for two numbers and calculate their sum.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Comparison
micro_exercises.task: Use comparison operators to compare two variables and print the result.

knowledge_check.question: What is a variable in Python?
knowledge_check.answer: A variable is a named location in memory used to store data.

knowledge_check.question: What is the difference between == and =?
knowledge_check.answer: '==' is a comparison operator, while '=' is an assignment operator.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise
main_exercise.task: Complete the main exercise for Variables and Operators

modules.title: Control Flow in Python
modules.description: Learn how to control the flow of your programs using conditional statements and loops.

lessons.title: If, Elif, and Else Statements
lessons.summary: Explore how to use conditional statements to control program flow.

hands_on_labs.title: Lab: Decision Making
hands_on_labs.goal: Create a program that makes decisions based on user input.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Simple If Statement
micro_exercises.task: Write a program that checks if a number is positive or negative.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Multiple Conditions
micro_exercises.task: Extend your program to check if the number is zero.

knowledge_check.question: What is the purpose of an if statement?
knowledge_check.answer: To execute code based on a condition.

knowledge_check.question: How do you write an elif statement?
knowledge_check.answer: Using the keyword 'elif' followed by a condition.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise
main_exercise.task: Complete the main exercise for If, Elif, and Else Statements

lessons.title: For Loops

hands_on_labs.goal: Create a program that processes items in a list using a for loop.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Basic For Loop
micro_exercises.task: Write a for loop that prints numbers from 1 to 10.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Looping Through a List

knowledge_check.question: What is the purpose of a for loop?
knowledge_check.answer: To iterate over a sequence or collection.

knowledge_check.question: How do you use the range() function?
knowledge_check.answer: By calling range(start, stop) to generate a sequence of numbers.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise

hands_on_labs.title: Lab: User Input Loop
hands_on_labs.goal: Create a program that continues to ask for user input until a specific condition is met.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Basic While Loop

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Using Break

knowledge_check.question: What is a while loop?
knowledge_check.answer: A loop that continues as long as a condition is true.

knowledge_check.question: What does the break statement do?
knowledge_check.answer: It exits the loop immediately.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise
main_exercise.task: Complete the main exercise for While Loops and Break/Continue

modules.title: Data Structures in Python
modules.description: Learn about lists, dictionaries, and how to manipulate data effectively.

lessons.summary: Explore how to create and manipulate lists in Python.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Create a List

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: List Methods

knowledge_check.question: How do you create a list in Python?
knowledge_check.answer: By using square brackets, e.g., colors = ['red', 'blue'].

knowledge_check.question: What does the append() method do?
knowledge_check.answer: It adds an item to the end of the list.

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Accessing Values
micro_exercises.task: Use the get() method to retrieve a value from your dictionary.

knowledge_check.question: What is a dictionary in Python?
knowledge_check.answer: A collection of key-value pairs.

knowledge_check.question: How do you access a value in a dictionary?
knowledge_check.answer: By using the key, e.g., my_dict['key'] or my_dict.get('key').

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise
main_exercise.task: Complete the main exercise for Dictionaries in Python

lessons.title: Tuples and Sets
lessons.summary: Understand tuples and sets as alternative data structures in Python.

hands_on_labs.title: Lab: Coordinate Storage

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Create a Tuple

micro_exercises.title: Exercise: Create a Set

knowledge_check.question: What is a tuple?
knowledge_check.answer: An immutable collection of items.

knowledge_check.question: How do you create a set?
knowledge_check.answer: By using curly braces or the set() function.

knowledge_check.question: What is a function?
knowledge_check.answer: A block of code that performs a specific task.

knowledge_check.question: How do you define a function in Python?

knowledge_check.question: What is a parameter?
knowledge_check.answer: A variable used in a function to accept input.

knowledge_check.question: How do you return a value from a function?
knowledge_check.answer: Using the return statement followed by the value.

main_exercise.title: Main Exercise

knowledge_check.answer: Using the import statement followed by the module name.

knowledge_check.answer: To extend functionality and reuse code.
